interestingcomments.content: Aesop - you touched-out the end of the serial number, correct?
interestingcomments.MarkedSent: Aesop - you touched-out the end of the serial number, correct?

interestingcomments.content: Yes, I have one of this last batch of cameras sent to Berlin on August 11th 1944. It is number 385733 and has the luftwaffen (German Airforce) markings with the Fl number on the top plate and Luftwaffen Eigentum (property of the German Airforce) on the back adjacent to the oculars. It also came with lens number 585936 that James Lager confirmed was sent as part of the package. Evidently the Leitz records stated that these were sent to Berlin but did not mention that they went to the German Airforce as a final destination. Originally when Jim Lager first saw one from this batch of 155 cameras in the 70s he thought they were fake! But then they kept showing up and finally he realized that at that late date in the war, Leitz was in such confusion that they did not put all the information regarding the airforce destination in the ledger. As to when the cameras were made, it is your guess. The serial numbers refer to cameras made in 1942 but then if you study the serial numbers of cameras made during the war there is great confusion. Some of the cameras received by the occupying US Army have serial numbers that indicate they were made in the earlier days before the occupation. I also have a camera made for the german army with the serial number 363624. It has Heer on the top plate and my research indicates that it is not a fake because many German service cameras were made in the serial numbers around that one (but who knows). But it is impossible to be sure as German Army cameras were seldom marked in the Leitz Ledger. Interestingly this camera was converted to a black dial IIIf with sync in the early 50s by using the original top plate (thank goodness) and screwing on the flash guide around the shutter speed dial, with two tiny screws, and placing the sync socket on the back near the oculars. The shutter speeds on the dial are IIIc ( 30-1) speeds not those found on the IIIf (25-1) cameras. Interestingly the camera was also given a sharkskin coating and the red curtains were replaced (too bad) with the newer black curtains. If I knew how to reduce the size of my files topost I would do it and post pictures of both cameras as they are very interesting. --img--
